ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: 3D cross product domain
ygData.msgSnippet: Chad, Further to my previous email I was thinking about what sort and how many test cases you would need in order to have a good attempt at evolving a network

Chad,

Further to my previous email I was thinking about what sort and how many 
test cases you would need in order to have a good attempt at evolving a 
network to do a 3D vector cross product. Here's what I came up with...

If you consider the origin of a (3D) cartesian coordinate system with 
vectors coming out at all angles in all 3 dimensions you have a sort of 
spikey sphere. You could then calculate the cross product of each of 
these vectors with every other vector, and this should give you a good 
enough set of examples for the neural net search to be able to 
specialize and also to cover every possible set of vectors that we might 
want to find a cross product for.

By my thinking the smallest set of vectors that fits the above scheme 
would have a set of vectors all seperated by 45 degrees, e.g. if we 
think of one plane at a time, here is the x,y plane (z=0):

                    View this in Courier New font if it looks a mess!
            y
         \  |  /
          \ | /
           \|/ 
      ------------ x
                             / | \
                           /   |   \
                         /     |     \


Here we have 8 vectors, each seperated by 45 degrees. If we then take 
this set of vectors and rotate it about the x axis by 45 degrees we get 
another set of vectors - repeat this two more times and you end up with 
26 vectors in all 3 dimensions that are evenly spread out and that form 
a spikey sphere :)

If we then compare each vector against itself and all of the others this 
then makes 26*26=676 test cases. Remember that we should compare each 
vector with itself so that we can be sure the network learns to generate 
the zero vector when comparing parallel vectors.

Of course it might be necessary to use an even larger set of vectors to 
improve the accuracy of the evolved network - I don't know, but I think 
the set described above is an absolute minimum.

I hope that was clear enough and helps out a bit,

Colin
